title: Beware the unintended consequences of staff appraisal methods
text:
In the case of scaling systems, people may end up unfairly placed despite performing well, which can work to the disadvantage of the individual and the business. That’s a more obvious unintended consequence, but there may be others, so you will need to think it through with those who administer the system – in your case HR and people managers.

There are plenty of examples of unintended consequences, from the implementation of a profanity filter by AOL in 1996 that ended up blocking residents of Scunthorpe, to the cane toads introduced in Queensland that can now be found down our coastline.

Good intentions do not always make for a strong defence. When the tech industry recently cited unintended consequences, it was accused of using “the usual weak excuse for bad policies”. You could take this as a warning for you to do your homework on the systems over which you reside, especially now that you’re the boss.

I worked with a person once who really did me over – they lied and were deceptive in cunning ways. Now our work paths are set to cross again. Many years may have passed and I’m now a senior leader (more senior than they are) but the memories are still there. Am I a bad person (or even unethical) because I can’t forgive and forget?

Some consider it a maxim to forgive and forget. It’s not just about “moving on”, it’s often seen as the higher moral position. We need only think of Nelson Mandela’s ability to forgive. He held that “forgiveness liberates the soul”.

Psychologists have confirmed that forgiving can be good for our emotional health. However, we’re not all capable of such noble acts, even for far lesser wrongdoings. Some have taken to distinguishing between forgiving and forgetting, focusing on the former.

Pop star Taylor Swift was referred to as a “Philosopher of Forgiveness” when she offered her insights after having been wronged. “People go on and on about you have to forgive and forget to move past something,” she said. “No, you don’t. You just become indifferent and then you move on.”

Some philosophers hold that there are valid reasons not to forgive and forget. Wrongdoings by people such as your former colleague can send a demeaning message that shouldn’t necessarily go unchallenged. Philosopher Dr Scott Hershovitz goes so far as to encourage people to resent. He cites another philosopher, Professor Pamela Hieronymi, who claims that when you resent, you protest the message, you insist, if only to yourself, that you do matter.

In a practical sense, the question is, can you work together? It might be an idea to get together beforehand and have an honest discussion to see if there’s an explanation for what happened and a commitment for things to be different this time – not lest you get bitten twice. If you’re not satisfied with what you hear then you could consider yourself obliged to speak to your colleagues.

If they are determined to bring the person on despite your experience, then you could heed the words of Oscar Wilde, who encouraged forgiveness for an entirely different reason, “Always forgive your enemies, nothing annoys them so much”.

Do you have an ethical dilemma at work? Send your questions to Clare Payne at AskClareAFR@gmail.com.
description: Management tools provide many ways to judge performance but they’re not foolproof.
